Indication: Loculated malignant effusion (Ovarian Ca).
Proc: Left Med Thoracoscopy + Adhesiolysis.
Findings: Multiple septations/loculations. 900mL drained.
Action: Blunt lysis of adhesions. Biopsies taken. 4g Talc slurry.
Plan: Chest tube to suction. Oncology f/u.
IP32650-006_syn_2:
PROCEDURE: Left medical thoracoscopy with adhesiolysis and pleurodesis.
INDICATION: 65-year-old female with metastatic ovarian carcinoma and complex, loculated pleural effusion.
DETAILS: Ultrasound revealed multiloculated fluid. Upon entry, extensive fibrinous adhesions were encountered. Blunt dissection was employed to break down septations and unify the pleural space, facilitating the drainage of 900 mL of fluid. Nodular implants were biopsied. Following adhesiolysis, 4 grams of talc slurry was instilled under direct visualization to ensure adequate coverage.
DISPOSITION: Admitted to oncology service.
IP32650-006_syn_3:
CPT: 32650 (includes adhesiolysis if not extensive enough for separate decortication code, typically).
Technique:
- Access: Left 6th ICS.
- Lysis: Blunt lysis of adhesions to treat loculations.
- Drainage: 900 mL.
- Biopsy: Parietal pleura.
- Pleurodesis: Talc slurry.
Reasoning: Standard thoracentesis failed due to loculations.

IP32650-006:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for loculated malignant pleural effusion.
Patient: [REDACTED], 65-year-old female with metastatic ovarian carcinoma and loculated left pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl; supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula.
Indication: Progressive dyspnea from loculated malignant pleural effusion not adequately drained by prior thoracentesis.
Procedure details: Bedside ultrasound showed multiple septations and loculations along the lateral left chest. A 2 cm incision was made at the 6th intercostal space, midaxillary line. Trocar insertion yielded 900 mL of serous fluid from the largest locule. A semi-rigid thoracoscope was advanced; adhesions were bluntly lysed to break down septations. Multiple parietal pleural biopsies were taken from nodular areas. After near-complete drainage, 4 g talc in 50 mL saline was instilled and distributed under direct visualization. A 20 Fr chest tube was placed and secured.
Complications: Mild pleuritic pain controlled with IV opioids; no hypotension or hypoxia.
Estimated blood loss: 30 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to oncology floor with chest tube to suction.
Plan: Transition to water seal on postoperative day 1; remove tube when drainage low; continue systemic chemotherapy per oncology.
